misc module¶

misc.IOP2AOP_Albert_Mobley_03(a, bb, theta_s=30, theta_v=0, windspd=7)¶

Estimates remote sensing reflectance (Rrs) from inherent optical properties (IOPs) using the Albert & Mobley (2003) model.

Parameters:

  • a (float or np.ndarray) – Total absorption coefficient (1/m).

  • bb (float or np.ndarray) – Total backscattering coefficient (1/m).

  • theta_s (float, optional) – Solar zenith angle in degrees (default is 30).

  • theta_v (float, optional) – Sensor/viewing zenith angle in degrees (default is 0).

  • windspd (float, optional) – Wind speed at the surface in m/s (default is 7).

Returns:

Rrs – Remote sensing reflectance (sr^-1) estimated from the input IOPs.

Return type:

float or np.ndarray

References

Albert, A. & Mobley, C.D. (2003). An analytical model for subsurface irradiance and remote sensing reflectance in deep and shallow case-2 waters. Optics Express, 11(22), 2873-2890.

misc.IOP2AOP_Lee_11(bbw, bbp, at, bbt, gw0=0.05881474, gw1=0.05062697, gp0=0.03997009, gp1=0.1398902)¶

Computes the remote sensing reflectance (rrs) using the Lee et al. (2011) IOP to AOP model.

Parameters:

  • bbw (float) – Backscattering coefficient of water.

  • bbp (float) – Backscattering coefficient of particles.

  • at (float) – Total absorption coefficient.

  • bbt (float) – Total backscattering coefficient.

  • gw0 (float, optional) – Empirical coefficient for water (default: 0.05881474).

  • gw1 (float, optional) – Empirical coefficient for water (default: 0.05062697).

  • gp0 (float, optional) – Empirical coefficient for particles (default: 0.03997009).

  • gp1 (float, optional) – Empirical coefficient for particles (default: 0.1398902).

Returns:

Remote sensing reflectance (rrs) calculated using the Lee et al. (2011) model.

Return type:

float

References

Lee, Z., et al. (2011). “An empirical formula to estimate remote sensing reflectance from inherent optical properties of natural waters.” Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans, 116(C2).

misc.def_frac(name, value, name_phyto)¶

Creates a numpy array of zeros with the same length as name_phyto, and sets the element corresponding to name to value.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name to search for in name_phyto.

  • value (float) – The value to assign at the index corresponding to name.

  • name_phyto (list of str) – List of names to use as reference for indexing.

Returns:

Array of zeros with value set at the index of name.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If name is not found in name_phyto.

misc.rnorm_bound(n, mean, sd=None, lo=-inf, up=inf, cv=None, **kwargs)¶

Generate random samples from a normal distribution with optional bounds. :param n: Number of samples to generate. :type n: int :param mean: Mean of the normal distribution. :type mean: float :param sd: Standard deviation of the normal distribution. Required if cv is not provided. :type sd: float, optional :param lo: Lower bound for the samples. Defaults to -np.inf (no lower bound). :type lo: float, optional :param up: Upper bound for the samples. Defaults to np.inf (no upper bound). :type up: float, optional :param cv: Coefficient of variation. If provided, sd is calculated as abs(cv * mean). :type cv: float, optional :param **kwargs: Additional keyword arguments (currently unused).

Returns:

Array of n samples drawn from the normal distribution, constrained between lo and up.

Return type:

np.ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If neither sd nor cv is provided.

Notes

  • This is probably very much not optimal and could be done in a much more reasonable way. However, this project is a direct port of the IOPModel from R to python and that is how it was in R.

misc.vec_to_mat(x, n, axis=1)¶

Converts a 1D vector into a 2D matrix by repeating it along the specified axis.

Parameters:

  • x (array_like) – Input 1D vector to be repeated.

  • n (int) – Number of repetitions along the specified axis.

  • axis (int, optional) – Axis along which to repeat the vector: - 1: Repeat as rows (default). - 2: Repeat as columns.

Returns:

result – 2D matrix with the vector repeated along the specified axis.

Return type:

ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If axis is not 1 or 2.

Examples

>>> vec_to_mat([1, 2, 3], 2, axis=1)
array([[1, 2, 3],
       [1, 2, 3]])

>>> vec_to_mat([1, 2, 3], 2, axis=2)
array([[1, 1],
       [2, 2],
       [3, 3]])
